questions.text: You are caring for a 65-year-old. He reports that he started having chest pain that sounds like classic angina. After 2 minutes, the angina subsides. This exertional limitation has been stable over the last year and he does not experience chest pain at other times. He is on no medications. You refer him for coronary angiography, which demonstrates a 70% stenosis in his mid-left anterior descending coronary artery. Left ventriculography shows normal ventricular systolic function. What is the next most reasonable course of action from those listed below?

options.label: A
options.text: Advise him to stop playing tennis

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate anti-anginal medical therapy with a beta blocker, statin, and aspirin

options.label: D
options.text: Percutaneous coronary intervention with a drug-eluting stent

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiate anti-anginal medical therapy with a beta blocker, statin, and aspirin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Initiate anti-anginal medical therapy with a beta blocker, statin, and aspirin. This patient has classic stable angina. Clinical trials have confirmed that with the initial diagnosis of stable ischemic heart disease, it is first appropriate to initiate a medical regimen as described.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A .- Revascularization should be employed in conjunction with, but not replace, the continuing need to modify risk factors and assess medical therapy. Option B, D .- Revascularization should be considered in the presence of unstable phases of the disease, intractable symptoms, severe ischemia or high-risk coronary anatomy, diabetes, and impaired left ventricular function.

questions.text: A 67-year-old fry chef presents to the emergency department with the sudden onset of crushing substernal chest pain. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and erectile dysfunction for which he takes daily amlodipine, simvastatin, and tadalafil. On your evaluation, his blood pressure is 145/85 and his heart rate is 90 beats/min. His lungs are clear and his jugular venous pulse is not elevated. There are no murmurs or gallops on cardiac auscultation. He continues to complain of chest discomfort, rating it an 8/10. Initial troponin I return elevated at 0.52 ng/dL (normal < 0.06 ng/dL) and electrocardiogram reveals 1-mm ST depression in II, III, aVF, V5, and V6. All of the following pharmacologic therapies are reasonable to administer EXCEPT -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nitroglycerin sublingually This patient is suffering from a non–ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). The two cornerstones of pharmacologic therapy in NSTEMI management are the reduction of myocardial oxygen demand and antithrombotic therapy targeted at a presumed partially occluding thrombus forming on disrupted atherothrombotic coronary plaque.

Highyeild:

unfractionated heparin (UFH) , long the mainstay of therapy; the low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), enoxaparin, which has been shown to be superior to UFH in reducing recurrent cardiac events, especially in patients managed by a conservative strategy but with some increase in bleeding; bivalirudin , a direct thrombin inhibitor that is similar in efficacy to either UFH or LMWH but causes less bleeding and is used just prior to and/or during percutaneous coronary intervention; and the indirect factor Xa inhibitor, fondaparinux, which is equivalent in efficacy to enoxaparin but appears to have a lower risk of major bleeding.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A,B -.Aspirin in combination with a P2Y12 receptor blocker (e.g., clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) are appropriate antiplatelet options. Option C .- Options for anticoagulants include

questions.text: You are seeing a 42-year-old woman with repeated presentations to the emergency department with chest pain. The pain usually has classic anginal qualities. On this presentation, she has transient ST elevations in leads V1–V4 as well as I and aVL that occurred with the pain. Troponin biomarkers are mildly elevated. On coronary angiography, she has no atherosclerosis. However, during the procedure when asked to hyperventilate, there is distinct vasospasm in the left anterior descending artery. All of the following are reasonable treatments for her EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aspirin This patient has Prinzmetal variant angina. Aspirin may actually increase the severity of ischemic episodes, possibly as a result of the sensitivity of coronary tone to modest changes in the synthesis of prostacyclin.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, D -Nitrates and calcium channel blockers are the main therapeutic agents. Option C . Statin therapy has been shown to reduce the risk of major adverse events, although the precise mechanism is not established. The response to beta-blockers is variable.

Extraedge:

Coronary revascularization may be helpful in patients who also have discrete, flow-limiting, proximal fixed obstructive lesions. Patients who have had ischemia-associated ventricular fibrillation despite maximal medical therapy should receive an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

questions.text: All of the following medications used in the acute management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction are appropriately matched to their mechanism of effect EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: Abciximab—inhibition of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nitroglycerin—reduced cardiac afterload All of these choices are appropriate therapy for patients with an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) in certain situations. While nitroglycerin is effective for anti-anginal effects in the setting of STEMI, it enacts those effects through decreasing preload and perhaps through some direct nitric oxide–induced coronary vasodilation. Nitroglycerin has minimal effect on systemic afterload.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.- Aspirin is an irreversible cyclooxygenase inhibitor and thus inhibits the production of thromboxane A2. Option B.- Abciximab and eptifibatide are glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors that also inhibit platelet aggregation. Option C.- Beta blockers reduce myocardial oxygen demand by reducing cardiac chronotropic and inotropy. They should be used with caution in patients with MI and any signs of delayed conduction (prolonged PR interval), heart failure, or risk for cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: Mr. Rahul underwent tissue plasminogen activator administration for acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction 1 hour previously. He had an excellent response with the resolution of his ST-segment elevation and chest pain; however, the nurse pages you to evaluate a change in his rhythm. You note a wide complex ventricular rhythm with a rate of 75 beats/min. Mr. Rahul continues to feel well without new symptoms and his blood pressure is 120/80. The next most appropriate therapeutic maneuver is which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer amiodarone 150 mg IV over 10 minutes

options.label: C
options.text: Administer metoprolol 5 mg IV every 5 minutes × 3

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continue observation This patient has an accelerated idioventricular rhythm, a common finding in patients with successful reperfusion after thrombolytic therapy . This rhythm is benign and requires no further therapy. It invariably resolves on its own .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Flecainide (a class I antiarrhythmic) is contraindicated in post–myocardial infarction patients as it was found to increase mortality in the CAST trial. Option A, C- Amiodarone or metoprolol would be appropriate therapy if this was ventricular tachycardia or perhaps supraventricular tachycardia. Carotid sinus massage would be appropriate in the setting of supraventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: Ms. Sunita is a 48-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation and peptic ulcer disease who is brought to your emergency department after 30 minutes of crushing substernal chest pain. Her blood pressure is 110/65 with an irregular heart rate of 85 beats/min and a resting room air oxygen saturation of 91%. Her electrocardiogram shows 3–4 mm ST-segment elevations in leads V2–V4. Your hospital is 4 hours from the nearest catheterization laboratory and the weather precludes air transport. Her medications include warfarin, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and losartan. Which of the following is a clear contraindication to administering an IV thrombolytic agent?

options.label: B
options.text: History of a cerebrovascular hemorrhage 2 years ago

questions.correct_answer: B. History of a cerebrovascular hemorrhage 2 years ago
questions.explanation:
Solution:

History of a cerebrovascular hemorrhage 2 years ago Clear contraindications to the use of fibrinolytic agents include a history of cerebrovascular hemorrhage at any time, a non-hemorrhagic stroke, or other cerebrovascular events within the past year.

Highyeild:

Absolute Contraindications for Thrombolytic Treatment Recent intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) Structural cerebral vascular lesion Intracranial neoplasm Ischemic stroke within three months Possible aortic dissection Active bleeding or bleeding diathesis (excluding menses) Significant head injury or facial trauma within three months Recent Intracranial or spinal surgery Severe uncontrolled hypertension For streptokinase, previous treatment within six months

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C - marked hypertension (a reliably determined systolic arterial pressure >180 mmHg and/or a diastolic pressure >110 mmHg) at any time during the acute presentation, suspicion of aortic dissection, and active internal bleeding (excluding menses) . While advanced age is associated with an increase in hemorrhagic complications, the benefit of fibrinolytic therapy in the elderly appears to justify its use if no other contraindications are present and the amount of myocardium in jeopardy appears to be substantial. Option D- Relative contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy, which require assessment of the risk-to-benefit ratio, include current use of anticoagulants (international normalized ratio ≥2), a recent (< 2 weeks) invasive or surgical procedure or prolonged (>10 minutes) cardiopulmonary resuscitation, known bleeding diathesis, pregnancy, a hemorrhagic ophthalmic condition (e.g., hemorrhagic diabetic retinopathy), active peptic ulcer disease, and a history of severe hypertension that is currently adequately controlled. Because of the risk of an allergic reaction, patients should not receive streptokinase if that agent had been received within the preceding 5 days to 2 years.

questions.text: An 80 yrs male with a known case of diabetes and hypertension came to the hospital with chest pain and profuse sweating. He was diagnosed with anterior wall myocardial infarction. Which of the following can be associated with the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above

Highyeild:

Sign of ventricular failure: Dyskinetic and bulging apex S4 and S3 heard. Decrease the intensity of S1. Pericardial friction rub.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. It causes sympathetic overactivity: In anterior wall myocardial infarction, there is stimulation of the sympathetic system. Option B. Presence of tachycardia: it results from stimulation of the sympathetic system in case of anterior wall myocardial infarction. Option C . Presence of hypertension: it results from stimulation of the sympathetic system in case of anterior wall myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A 70 yrs male came to the casualty with sudden onset crushing type of chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. His ECG is shown below: Which of the following can be associated with the possible diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above

Highyeild:

Sign of ventricular failure: Dyskinetic and bulging apex S4 and S3 heard. Decrease the intensity of S1. Pericardial friction rub.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.- It causes parasympathetic overactivity: the above case is of inferior wall myocardial infarction, hence there is parasympathetic stimulation. Option B .- Presence of bradycardia : it results from parasympathetic system stimulation in inferior wall myocardial infarction. Option C .- Presence of hypotension : it results from parasympathetic system stimulation in inferior wall myocardial infarction.
